texts.definition: Abilities gained during gameplay that allows for new actions to be performed.
markups: <style="Definition">Abilities gained during gameplay that allows for new actions to be performed.</style>

Many games provide players with additional actions that they can perform after they have started playing. These <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> often give players more freedom in the games and allow them to be more empowered as gameplay continues.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> make use of character levels and when players reach new levels, players are awarded with <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style>.

This has been carried over to Computer-based Roleplaying Games such as the Neverwinter Nights and Dragon Age series, and the Fallout series where players get perks at every other character level gained. The Legend of Zelda series does likewise but ties New Abilities more to the possession of new tools.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> allows players to gain experience in several different skills during game play. When players "level up" in a skill, they gain <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> connected to that skill, e. g., being able to call air strikes based on observation with binoculars, fully reviving team mates with health injections, or having more ammunition in supply packs.

Becoming a zombie in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombiepox">Zombiepox</link></style> does not automatically mean game over, since players can cure themselves by finding brains. However, when being zombies the players' avatars gain the ability to spread the zombie disease just like other zombies, which does not aid in their long-term success in the game.

Picking up power-ups in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mario%20Kart%20series">Mario Kart series</link></style> gives players <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> for a certain limit time or limited number of uses.

<style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> in games are most often given to provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> (e.g. by giving players access to new <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>), but can also be added because they are needed to overcome particular challenges already decided upon. Besides what <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> should be given, the primary design choices for <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> lies in if the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> are linked to specific <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> or more generally to players, if players can affect what <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> is gained, and if the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> gained are <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style> due to having <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>. Although any <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> may be <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style> can be mentioned since they are <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> but may be mistaken for <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>. The difference between <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> and <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> can be defined in several different ways: if the new actions are activated in the same way as the old, if the consequences of the actions affect different parts of the game state, or if the explanation given by the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> differentiates them. However, the distinction between them may be blurry for players and it may be prudent to consider both patterns when designing one or the other.

<style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> given to specific <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can be tied to acquiring specific game elements such as <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>, new types of <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>. All of these can thereby be used to instantiate <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> with the exception of <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> which due to being a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> instead can given variants through <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style>. The <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> can also be motivated as personal development in the form of new <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, possibly as the effects of gaining <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>. When the use of <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> is tied to the use of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, simply gaining access to a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> one didn't have before makes one have a <style="CurrentLink">New Ability</style>. Gaining <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and becoming members of <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> can also do this in a roundabout way since this may let players have access to new services from <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> that are members in the <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. All these ways but the last can be used to make the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> and allow <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> of the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> through for example <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style>. Other ways of introducing <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> depend more on tying them directly to the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, for example through introducing <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> or by creating <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> that are defined by the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> they provide. This makes the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> into <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and makes players have to move the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> there to get the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. The placement of <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> provide similar options but here getting to particular places (at the right time) becomes important and one then gets the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> with a <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limit</link></style>. These approaches can be used for <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> as well. When done so, they increase the value of individual <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, but unless the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> are also <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style> due to <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, this may make them more into <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> than <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Games which allow the <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> of enemy <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> can give players <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> through these "converted" <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Non-localized ways of giving <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> are through <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, or results of <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> such as advances in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style>, and these options can be applied to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or classes of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style> can also do this on a temporary basis.

While the above shows how New Abilities can be given to several types of Focus Loci, Cards and Bookkeeping Tokens can be Focus Loci that give players New Abilities by being put into play (and thereby affect how player can interact with Game Worlds). For Cards, players can be given these New Abilities through performing Card or Deck Building.

<style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> may be preordained by <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, forced upon players due to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Role%20Reversal">Role Reversal</link></style> events, or they may be given the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to select which to get from a set of <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. Giving players a control over what <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> they gain and letting the information about the possible <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> be made available in advance allows for <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Play">Team Play</link></style>, this also allows <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style>. While any <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> can be <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> until other acquire them as well, <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> can be designed to be <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> by only letting one or a few players get the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. This may be done through the game elements providing the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> being limited in number.

Like <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> can affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> negatively. This may be countered by the <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> of linking the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> to <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> of another type, forcing players to perform <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Off</link></style> choices. Another way to provide <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> is to have the actions provided by the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> extend a set action that need to be paid for by <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> - so using the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> means not using old ones. Putting <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> on how long players have the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> - as is often done with <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> - is a third way of balancing <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style>.

While New Abilities are often given as Rewards (or more precisely Facilitating Rewards), having diseases and the ability to spread them is an example of how New Abilities can be Penalties; this can be found in Zombiepox, Team Fortress Classic and caused the Corrupted Blood incident in World of Warcraft.

To let other players know what <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> players have acquired one can change the representation of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> accordingly. Generally, <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> fits less well with a game's <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> than <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> unless they are presented through game elements, <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, or have been part of <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style>.

In computer-based games where players have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> in what <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> to get from raises in <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>, this is typically done in <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>.
From a pure interface perspective, placing <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style> can instantiate <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style>.

As stated above, <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> may be part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> but can also create narratives through the <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> they embody, especially when they can be seen as the effects of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> - quite obviously - give players new <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> in games. They do this through changing what action the players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, can do. The ability to have more influence over the game state makes goals of acquiring <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> into implicit if not explicit <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or acquiring new <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>  - <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> are examples of game elements that make these goals explicit especially since the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> also typically are <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. As they give players increased <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> may be <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, receiving them is almost always considered a <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> and can give players the feeling of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style>. This may give players an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> even if no actual influence exists, as for example in the cases where <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style> exist due to the <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> are matched by <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>.

The timing of when <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> are made available to players are often critical to when and if phases of <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style>, or

<style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> occur (it does not affect <style="Link"><link="extermination">Extermination</link></style> to the same degree since players typically have those abilities at hand already).

Giving <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> as the gameplay unfolds can help players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> and provides a means to support <style="Link"><link="increasing-rewards">Increasing Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> over a game session. They can temporarily lower players ability to have a <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> given to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> (and if the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> are chosen these choices can be seen as <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>) and likewise a form of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> when given to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> also creates <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>. This <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> can in turn provide the development of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style> structures but also problems with <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiplayer%20games">Multiplayer games</link></style>] (and <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">New Abilities</style> can provide <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> when whom they are given to and what actions are given is based upon players' current gameplay ranking.

<style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="card-building">Card Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="increasing-rewards">Increasing Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Role%20Reversal">Role Reversal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>
